title: Fascinating landscape, ruins in Georgia — not that one
text:
Fascinating landscape, ruins in Georgia — not that one Ned Blac , San Francisco Chronicle By Ned Black Published 8:24 pm, Thursday, August 20, 2015 Ned Black and Monica Milstein of Mill Valley in the Upper Svaneti region of the Caucasus Mountains. Ned Black and Monica Milstein of Mill Valley in the Upper Svaneti... 
Massive blazes across dry West drain firefighting resources Page 1 of 1 
Why I went: A National Geographic article on the horses, history and remoteness of this region, and the chapters on Georgia in John Steinbeck ’s 1948 “A Russian Journal” intrigued us. 
Don’t miss: The Svaneti region in the Caucasus Mountains has stunning valleys, peaks and glaciers. The 1,000-year-old cave monasteries at Davit Gareja and Vardzia are fascinating. 
Don’t bother: Trying to pay with a credit card. Most places take cash only. ATMs are available in the cities. 
Coolest souvenir: Exquisite cloisonne pendants made by Orthodox monks sold at Pokany shop in old town Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia. 
Worth a splurge: Private guides. Trail markers are not maintained, and historical sites have few explanatory signs. At Davit Gareja you would not know to climb over a ridge to see frescoes undamaged by the Soviets. 
Wish I’d packed: A small, unobtrusive hat. Georgians rarely wear hats, and my large hiking hat stuck out like a billboard. 
Other comments: Many conquerors have come through Georgia, so its history is very diverse. Take a Russian phrasebook. Georgian ones aren’t available, and most people speak Russian. Georgians seldom smile but are very helpful and glad you’ve come to visit.
